data.title: Rethinking Sacrifice in the Pseudo-Clementines Homilies
data.abstractNote: Contrary to commonplace assumptions about the early Christian supersession of sacrifice, recent research has revealed the rarity of the complete rejection of sacrifice in the ancient Mediterranean world; even among Christians, critiques of sanctified animal slaughter more often functioned as authority claims over its ideal or proper practice. In light of this research, this article revisits the infamously negative attitude toward both biblical and “pagan” animal sacrifice in the Pseudo-Clementine literature, analyzing the dynamics of its rejection of sacrifice as simultaneously a theorization of sacrifice.
